choices.text:
by walking. I started from this nice hotel…

And ended up at the local markets…

Most importantly of all, being in Bhutan also allowed me to see the creation of some Buddhist sacred art known as thangkas. These kind of artworks are considered around the world as a form of Buddhist object of worship. While technically they are art, their dynamics are certainly closer to devotional worship. Despite the distinction, these kind of artworks allow me to use my skills for better cultural ends. I always wanted to use my skills to help others. With thangkas, I am able to do this primarily through helping monks to reproduce thangkas for their local use. Since all students in Bhutan are required to study Buddhism in school, these artworks are used to help teach and perpetuate the Buddhist culture throughout the country and beyond. I would argue the Bhutanese do a much more admirable job and appreciate the importance of religious/spiritual art better than my culture (Israel).

In this video, I filmed the creation of a Tibetan thangka. It helps to listen to John Lennon’s music as you watch because the music closes off the artist’s sound and brings focus to the process. Here is a complete thangka of Buddha, the process takes a few weeks and requires many hours of labor. In the video, it lasts about a minute so it may be easier for people with less attention span to such things. In the beginning, a monk draws the outline…
